text:
Donald Trump has become the 45th President
of the United States.

How will his administration change the course
of science and, more specifically, chemistry?

The best answer we’ve got right now is ¯\_(ツ)_/¯,
but that doesn’t mean there’s not a story.

It means now’s a good time to start following
the money.

Federal funding for non-defense R&D has been
hovering around $70 billion annually since
about 2001.

But experts are concerned that sum could drop
with a Republican controlled Congress and
Trump at the helm of the executive branch.

That’s not to say Republicans don’t support
basic science research.

Lawmakers on both sides of the aisle recently
passed the 21st Century Cures Act, designed
to spur medical innovation.

Rather, many Republicans are pushing for cuts
to all discretionary funding.
That includes money for scientific research.

Republicans’ budgetary shears could be made
razor sharp with Trump’s pick for the director

of the White House Office of Management & Budget,
Mick Mulvaney, who’s been described as a
fiscal hawk.

The legislation keeping the government funded
right now is set to expire in April.

By then, we could have a clearer picture of
the fiscal priorities of Congress and the
Trump administration.

With the government poised to tighten its
purse strings, some researchers think climate

science will face particularly aggressive
cuts.

After the election, a group of “guerilla
archivists” actually started backing up
government climate data to independent servers.

The fears are fueled by Trump’s skepticism
over climate change, which he has tempered
recently.

But during his campaign, he did vow to cancel
the landmark Paris Agreement to curb greenhouse
gas emissions and rising temperatures.

Another source of concern is an op-ed piece
written by two Trump advisors saying NASA

should shed its Earth-observing missions and
focus on space exploration.

Although the piece added that Earth observing
should be handled instead by other agencies,

none currently has capabilities that match
NASA’s.

Cutting NASA’s Earth-observing missions
could leave substantial gaps in our ability

to monitor our planet and hamstring climate
science and several other fields that rely

on satellite data, including forestry, agriculture,
and weather forecasting.

NASA officials tried to cast calm last month
by pointing out that Trump has yet to fill
key science posts, including NASA’s administrator.

Until those roles are filled, much of the
discussion now is speculative noise and not
meaningful signal, the officials said.
Still, not everyone shares this measured optimism.

Kevin Trenberth, a senior scientist for the
National Center for Atmospheric Research,

still worries that even temporary cuts to
NASA’s Earth studies could have lasting

effects on America’s leadership in Earth
and climate science.

NASA grants play a central role in supporting
young scientists working to better understand

our planet and that support could be on the
chopping block, Kevin tells us.

Kevin: The aspect that worries me most, one
of the casualties are graduate students and
the next generation of scientists.

Matt: Trump has promised to lift restrictions
on American energy producers, support fracking,

and encourage the use of natural gas, which
are all exciting prospects to U.S. chemical
makers.

To explain why, we visited Cal Dooley, president
and CEO of the American Chemistry Council,

a trade association of chemical manufacturers,
including Dow, DuPont, and ExxonMobil Chemical
Company.

Cal: We use natural gas as our feedstock in
the chemical industry.

We break those molecules apart and make all
of the chemical products that go into 96%

of the consumer products that people touch
every day.

Matt: Cal says he’s certain the incoming
administration understands the need for regulations

that address health and environmental concerns
without placing undue burden on American energy
producers.

But that doesn’t mean the chemical industry
agrees with all of the administration’s
proposed policies.

Under current international trade deals, the
chemical industry has become one of the country’s
leading exporters.

Trump’s trade plans call for protecting
American jobs by pulling back from those trade
deals, which would restrict U.S. exports.

Cal: The American Chemistry Council and our
member companies are committed to trade liberalization.

Actions that actually impede trade liberalization--that
increase tariffs--are problematic for the

chemical industry and a lot of our customers
downstream.

Matt: We’ve only grazed the tip of the iceberg
that is the Trump presidency.

We haven’t even touched on drug prices,
vaccines, cabinet picks, let alone anything

happening at the Environmental Protection
Agency, the Department of Energy, or the National
Institutes of Health.

But C&EN’s expert staff is covering all
of that and more.
